Current Issues in the Philosophy of Science (1961), and, more recently, B.Brody, Readings in the Philosophy of Science

is entitled The Philosophy of Rudolf Carnap (1963), and is an invaluable guide to the work of that great analyst. Each volume in this remarkable series begins with an autobiographical sketch by the philosopher, followed by critical essays by equally distinguished colleagues, the philosopher then replies, and the book closes with a comprehensive bibliography. For articles dealing with the subsequent development of some of Carnap’s pathbreaking ideas

title: Consultations with journals and collections of articles should also be fruitful; for example, P.Achinstein and S.Barker, The Legacy of Logical Positivism

contains an excellent collection of critical articles on the impact of positivism. The preeminent journals are Philosophy of Science, British Journal for the Philosophy of Science, and Synthese. title: and The Ultimate Foundation of Economic Science

but the first seven chapters of Human Action: A Treatise on Economics (1949, 1966) is probably the best introduction to praxeological reasoning. Hayek’s major methodological contribution is ‘Scientism and the Study of Society,’ reprinted in The Counter-Revolution of Science (1952, 1979); other books containing articles on methodology are his Studies in Philosophy, Politics and Economics (1967) and New Studies in Philosophy, Politics, Economics and the History of Ideas

The last includes his Nobel Lecture, ‘The Pretence of Knowledge.’ Modern Austrians are also interested in methodology: articles by J.Egger, I.Kirzner, M.Rizzo, and M.Rothbard in the introductory collections
